questions.text: A 32-year-old woman brings her 3-year-old son to the clinic. She is concerned about food safety and asks about the best method to ensure the milk she gives to her child is free from harmful bacteria. As part of your explanation about the pasteurization process, you informed her about the standard temperature and time required to pasteurize milk effectively. Which of the following is the correct combination of temperature and time for the pasteurization of milk?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 63°C for 30 min

 

Option D:


Pasteurization of milk is a process used to kill harmful bacteria without significantly changing the milk's nutritional value or flavor. Two methods are used for pasteurization of milk , the Holder method with a temperature of 63°C for 30 min or Flash method (72°C for 20 sec) followed by rapid cooling to 13°C. This method is effective in killing most bacteria and pathogens found in milk while preserving its quality. All non-spring pathogens are killed except Coxiella which survives Holder’s method.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 73°C for 20 min - This combination of temperature and time is excessive for pasteurization and could lead to changes in the nutritional quality and flavor of the milk.

 

Option B. 63°C for 20 min - This temperature is correct for pasteurization, but the duration is too long, which can lead to alterations in the milk's properties.

 

Option C. 73°C for 30 secs - This temperature is higher than necessary for effective pasteurization and can cause unnecessary changes to the milk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pasteurization of milk is a process used to kill harmful bacteria without significantly changing the milk's nutritional value or flavor. Two methods are used for pasteurization of milk , the Holder method with a temperature of 63°C for 30 min or Flash method (72°C for 20 sec) followed by rapid cooling to 13°C. This method is effective in killing most bacteria and pathogens found in milk while preserving its quality. All non-spring pathogens are killed except Coxiella which survives Holder’s method  

 

Ref: Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p33, 2/e p33, Ananthanarayan 10/e p30

questions.text: A 45-year-old lab technician is responsible for ensuring the proper sterilization of surgical instruments in a hospital. Recently, the hospital implemented a new autoclave machine. The technician wants to verify the efficacy of the autoclaving process. Which biological indicator should she use to determine the effectiveness of this sterilization method?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bacillus stearothermophilus

 

Option C:

 

Bacillus stearothermophilus is a thermophilic bacterium whose spores are used as a biological indicator for autoclaving. This bacterium is chosen because it is more resistant to heat than most pathogens, making it an ideal benchmark. If the autoclave can effectively kill these spores, it is assumed to be able to kill less resistant organisms, thus ensuring proper sterilization.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: This bacterium is not typically used as a biological indicator for autoclaving. It is more often associated with hospital-acquired infections.

 

Option B. Clostridium perfringens: While also a spore-forming bacterium, it is not commonly used as a standard for testing autoclave efficacy.

 

Option D. Salmonella typhi: This is a pathogenic bacterium causing typhoid fever and is not used as a biological indicator in autoclaving.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology/p40, 2/e p42, Ananthanarayan 10/e P32

questions.text: A microbiologist is giving a lecture on sterilization techniques and their effectiveness against various forms of life. One of the students asks about the organism most resistant to sterilization processes. Which of the following is the most resistant to sterilization?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prions

 

Option B:

 

Prion diseases are caused by infectious protein particles known as prions, which lack nucleic acid. They are resistant to many sterilization agents and can cause diseases in humans and animals, with Scrapie being a prototype. 

 

Some important Points –

 

  • Prion diseases have a long incubation period, 
  •  Symptoms include loss of muscle control, tremors, and rapidly progressive dementia, leading to death within a year of onset.
  • Animal prion diseases include Scrapie in sheep, mink encephalopathy, and bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE) or mad cow disease. Human prion diseases include Kuru, Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD), and variant CJD, which is linked to BSE-contaminated beef consumption.

 

Diagnosis involves measuring PrPSc, neuropathological diagnosis in brain biopsies, sequencing the PRNP gene, and abnormal EEG patterns. However, there's no effective therapy for prion diseases, with treatments like quinacrine and anti-PrP antibodies showing limited success.

 

Explanation:


Option A. Cysts - While cysts of protozoa are resistant to many disinfectants, they are not as resistant as prions.
 

Option C. Spores - Bacterial spores (like those of Bacillus and Clostridium species) are highly resistant to many sterilization techniques but less so compared to prions.
 

Option D. Viruses - Viruses vary in their resistance to sterilization but are generally less resistant than prions.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Prions are the most resistant to sterilization methods. They are misfolded proteins that can cause neurodegenerative diseases and are extremely difficult to destroy because they do not contain nucleic acids and have a structure that is highly resistant to heat, radiation, and most chemical disinfectants.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p31, 2/e p32, Patrick Murray 9/e p69

questions.text: A surgical team is discussing the use of STERRAD, a gas plasma sterilizer, in their operation theater for disinfecting surgical instruments. The team is curious about the active agent used in this sterilization method. Which of the following is the active agent used in STERRAD gas plasma sterilizers?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) H2O2 (Hydrogen Peroxide)

 

Option A:
 

STERRAD sterilizers use low-temperature hydrogen peroxide gas plasma for sterilization. Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is a strong oxidizing agent that destroys microorganisms through oxidation of cellular components. This method is effective and leaves no toxic residues, making it suitable for sensitive medical equipment.

 

This is recently introduced sterilization method (e.g. Sterrad and Plazlyte) used for creating plasma state, so as to maintain a uniform vacuum inside the chamber.

 

  • Chemical sterilants such as H2O2 alone or a mixture of H2O2 and peracetic acid
  •  Active agent is Ultraviolet (UV) photons and radicals (e.g., O and OH): Kill microorganisms and spores.
  • Low temperature is maintained (37–44°C). So best for heat labile surgical instruments. Sterilization control: Geobacillus stearothermophilus.

 

Explanation:


Option B. N2O. Nitrous oxide is not used in STERRAD sterilizers.
 

Option C. Ozone. While ozone is a powerful disinfectant, it is not the active agent in STERRAD systems.
 

Option D. EtO. Ethylene oxide is used for sterilizing heat-sensitive items due to their high penetration power and effectiveness against microorganisms and spores. The process works by EtO combining with cell proteins to achieve sterilization. Despite its effectiveness, EtO poses significant safety risks as it is highly inflammable, irritant, explosive, and carcinogenic. To mitigate these risks, it is typically supplied in a concentration of 10% to 20% mixed with inert gases. The sterilization conditions for EtO involve a concentration of 700 mg/liter and 40–80% relative humidity. Sterilization is achieved within 4–5 hours at 38°C or 1 hour at 55°C. 

 

Bacillus atrophaeus is used for sterilization control. 

 

EtO sterilization is particularly useful for items like disposable plastic petri dishes, syringes, heart-lung machines, sutures, catheters, respirators, and dental equipment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

STERRAD sterilizers utilize low-temperature hydrogen peroxide gas plasma for sterilization, a method effective for sensitive medical equipment due to the strong oxidizing nature of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). This method, which leaves no toxic residues, involves oxidation of cellular components of microorganisms, including spores, by H2O2 and is enhanced by UV photons and radicals like oxygen (O) and hydroxyl (OH). The process operates at a low temperature (37–44°C), ideal for heat-labile surgical instruments. Geobacillus stearothermophilus is used for sterilization control.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p39

questions.text: In a training session for operating theater staff, the topic of best practices for cleaning blood spills is discussed. The staff is asked about the most appropriate disinfectant to use for this purpose. Which of the following disinfectants is recommended for cleaning blood spills in an operating theater?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chlorine based

 

Option A:
 

Chlorine-based disinfectants are recommended for cleaning blood spills due to their broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity, including effectiveness against bloodborne pathogens. These disinfectants are capable of inactivating a wide range of microorganisms, including viruses, bacteria, and fungi.

Spill management should be carried out by hypochlorite- 1% for small spill and 10% for large spill

 

Explanation:
 

Option B. Phenol based - While effective against many microbes, phenol-based disinfectants are less preferred due to their potential toxicity and odor.
 

Option C. Alcohol based - Alcohols are effective disinfectants but may not be the best choice for blood spills due to their inability to inactivate certain pathogens in the presence of organic matter.
 

Option D. Quaternary ammonium compound - These are good for surface disinfection but less effective against certain viruses and spores, making them less ideal for blood spill cleanup.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For cleaning blood spills, chlorine-based disinfectants are the recommended choice due to their broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity. These disinfectants effectively inactivate a wide range of microorganisms, including viruses, bacteria, and fungi, making them suitable for handling bloodborne pathogens. 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Med. Microbiology 2/e p39, Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of hospital infection control 1/e, chapter 15.

questions.text: A cardiac surgeon is discussing the best sterilization method for a heart-lung machine with a team of technicians. Given the sensitivity and complexity of the equipment, which of the following methods is most suitable for sterilizing a heart-lung machine?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ethylene oxide

 

Option B:
 

Ethylene oxide (EtO) is the preferred sterilizing agent for heat-sensitive and complex medical devices such as heart-lung machines. Its effectiveness against all types of microorganisms, including spores, and its excellent penetration capabilities make it an ideal choice. However, it is important to conduct aeration post-sterilization to eliminate any residual EtO gas, due to its potential toxicity. 

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. Cidex (Glutaraldehyde) - It is a high-level disinfectant but may not be suitable for complex machinery like a heart-lung machine.
 

Option C. Isopropyl alcohol - It's a disinfectant, not a sterilant.
 

Option D. Formaldehyde - While effective, it is more commonly used for sterilizing heat-sensitive materials in a controlled environment, not for complex equipment like heart-lung machines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ethylene oxide (EtO) is the best choice for sterilizing heat-sensitive and complex medical devices like heart-lung machines. It is effective against all microorganisms, including spores, and penetrates well, but it requires aeration post-sterilization to remove any residual gas.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p41, 2/e p41, Ananthanarayan 10/e p34

questions.text: During a hospital infection control meeting, a debate arises about the Spaulding classification system for disinfection and sterilization. One of the statements made about the classification is incorrect. Which of the following statements about the Spaulding classification is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Semicritical items need low disinfectant

 

Option C:
 

The false statement is that semicritical items need low-level disinfectants. Semicritical items, which contact mucous membranes or non-intact skin, require high-level disinfection, not just low-level disinfection.

 

Semicritical items are those that come in contact with mucous membranes or minor skin breaches and they need high level disinfectant for sterilization.

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. True - Noncritical items are included in the Spaulding classification and typically require less stringent disinfection.
 

Option B. True - Semicritical items do contact with mucous membranes.
 

Option D.- Cardiac catheters are considered critical items as they enter sterile areas of the body and require sterilization.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p42, 2/e p44, Ananthanarayan 10/e p35

questions.text: A laboratory technician is instructed to disinfect sputum samples before analysis. However, they are advised to avoid using one particular disinfectant as it is not effective for this purpose. Which of the following is NOT an effective disinfectant for sputum?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chlorhexidine

 

Option D:
 

Chlorhexidine, while effective against a range of microorganisms, is not effective for disinfecting sputum. Sputum contains organic matter that can inactivate certain disinfectants, and chlorhexidine is less effective in the presence of organic material.

 

Explanation:
 

Option A. Autoclaving - Effective in sterilizing sputum samples.
 

Option B. Boiling - Can also be effective in disinfecting sputum.


Option C. Cresol - A potent disinfectant, effective against a variety of pathogens in sputum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p30, 2/e p44

choices.text: Cetrimide + Butyl alcohol
Cetrimide + Chlorhexidine + Butyl alcohol

questions.text: A nurse is preparing a solution for cleaning wounds and needs to know the active components of Savlon, a commonly used antiseptic. Which of the following constitutes the active ingredients in Savlon?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cetrimide + Chlorhexidine

 

Option A:


Savlon contains two active ingredients: cetrimide and chlorhexidine. Cetrimide is a quaternary ammonium compound with detergent and antiseptic properties, while chlorhexidine is a broad-spectrum biocide effective against a range of bacteria, viruses, and fungi.

 

Explanation:
 

Option B. Cetrimide + Butyl alcohol - This combination is not the active ingredient in Savlon.
 

Option C. Cetrimide + Chlorhexidine + Butyl alcohol - Butyl alcohol is not a component of Savlon.
 

Option D. Cetrimide + Cetavlon - Cetavlon is not an active ingredient in Savlon.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Savlon, a widely used antiseptic, primarily contains two active ingredients: cetrimide and chlorhexidine. Cetrimide, a quaternary ammonium compound, offers detergent and antiseptic properties. Chlorhexidine, on the other hand, is a broad-spectrum biocide effective against various bacteria, viruses, and fungi. This combination makes Savlon effective for cleansing and disinfection purposes.

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p39

questions.text: In a training session for new hospital staff, the topic of evaluating the efficacy of disinfectants is being discussed. The instructor mentions a specific coefficient that is used as a standard to measure the effectiveness of a disinfectant. What does the phenol coefficient - (Rideal Walker) test indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Efficacy of a disinfectant

 

Option A:
 

Testing efficacy of disinfectants by Phenol coefficient (Rideal Walker) test - Phenol coefficient is determined by the dilution of the disinfectant in question which sterilizes the suspension of S. typhi in a given time divided by the dilution of phenol which sterilizes the suspension in the same time.

 

Explanation:
 

Option B. Dilution of a disinfectant - The phenol coefficient does not indicate the dilution of a disinfectant.
 

Option C. Quantity of a disinfectant - It does not represent the quantity of the disinfectant used.
 

Option D. Purity of a disinfectant - The phenol coefficient does not measure the purity of a disinfectant.

 

Educational Objectives: 

 

 

Ref: Apurba Sastry’s Essentials of Medical Microbiology 1/e p40, 2/e p41, Ananthanarayan 10/e p35.
